ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Christopher Kruse  TA was very helpful, available and always ready to help
Instructor: Shuang Zhang  I didn't interact with my teaching assistants. Would be surprised in anyone did except via cryptic comments on graded assignments!
Instructor: Shuang Zhang  Shuang Zhang

Instructor: Shuang Zhang  Shuang was a fantastic TF - very responsive, very helpful, and very knowledgeable about all the material. I'm really glad he was my TA because I don't think I could have understand a lot of the material on the problems sets without his help. He was always very patient with me, answered all my questions clearly, and was genuinely helpful with everything.
Instructor: Shuang Zhang  I didn't interact with any of them really.
Instructor: Shuang Zhang  I interacted mostly with Shuang Zhnag
Instructor: Shuang Zhang  None of them. I never interacted with any of the TFs.
Instructor: Zhen Liu  Chris, Zhen and Shuang.
Instructor: Zhen Liu  Zhen

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Christopher Kruse  TAs were available, but I think some of the assignments require a lot of research and time. I believe TAs could be more helpful, mostly when one has spent hours on an assignment. I would suggest drop in sessions where students could come and ask questions. The point should be to really understand and not to be challenged

Instructor: Shuang Zhang  The teaching assistants seemed to lack understanding of the concepts themselves when grading assignments. Given that we never received answers to the assignments (which would have been useful for studying), they could have let us know why a question was wrong...

Instructor: Shuang Zhang  TA's made themselves available and were responsive on email. TA's should provide more feedback on homework assignments. TA's should be sure to always mark why each question was wrong, and include the correct answer. Point deductions seemed excessive at times.

Instructor: Shuang Zhang  Shuang was great at explaining conceptual material and always happy to help. I've met with all of the TFs for this class and I can say for sure that he was certainly the best one.

Instructor: Shuang Zhang  He was very helpful in teaching some of the concepts I could not understand in class and also very helpful in understanding assignments. He is willing to even explain to you beyond his office hours which was great given he is also busy.
Instructor: Zhen Liu  I wish the teaching assistants held a discussion/review session to ask questions about the problem sets in a larger group rather than having to go to one-on-one office hours.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This class did not seem particularly organized. There were not additional materials for non-engineering students to get caught up with the material. The instructors seemed to have a strong understanding of the technical aspects of the renewable energy technologies, but very little knowledge of the energy system as a whole.

Given the book was at far too of a junior level for the course, one would hope that the lecture slides would have been more useful for learning, but they are difficult to get through. Variables for equations change on the same lecture and are often unlabeled. I am also not sure what the logic was behind having the midterm include material on a problem set we hadn't even turned in yet... How can students have the time to know whether they understand the concept if haven't even had a chance to work problems yet? It wasn't like there was a lack of material to put on that test.

Prof. Smith did a good job teaching the course, but the material that was covered by Schwartz was not presented clearly. The slides were confusing and had a lot of extraneous information that really was not all that appropriate for the course, and it seemed like most variables in his equations were not well-defined so they were difficult for me to understand. Schwartz is clearly an expert in his field, but since this is a course on renewable energy and not physics, I think it would be better to have an instructor who specializes in the renewable energy technologies that we covered.

I think the course was valuable to people with very little background knowledge in this subject. For me, I came in with an engineering background and some professional experience, and didn't really learn anything new. I don't really blame the course, I just wish there was a more advanced equivalent for those with some background knowledge and comfort with more advanced concepts, and taught by professors with more of a working knowledge of the latest technologies and trends.

This course provides a clear and comprehensive understanding of renewable energy. Two things impressed me most: the clarity of explanations provided by the instructors and the content of the text book. I believe that students in the class were really passionate and interested, but some of the homework required a substantial background knowledge. I would suggest that TAs/instructors hold drop in sessions in a classroom where students can ask questions on the assignments, get some feedback on the way they approach the assignment, etc... Students will benefit more, regardless of the grades.
It should be made clear from the start that the course will be quantitatively focused and require basic physics skills.
The content was incredible, but the teaching was marginal, as was the textbook and class discussion. It should be structured differently.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Breadth of material, exposure to engineering and physics behind renewable energy technologies.
Very detailed instructions of every kinds of renewable energy.
The problem sets were challenging in the right ways and offered a chance to really learn the concepts. Loved the field trips and opportunity to see some of the technologies we discussed in class.
Problem sets were extremely valuable. I enjoyed the balance between quantitative and qualitative problems.
Covering a range of different renewable energy technologies - I appreciated the scope of the course.

This appears to be the only course on renewable energy available to FES students. I think I did learn a lot about the technical aspects of renewables and that's important for anyone interested in energy.
Almost every aspect of the course was excellent
I gained a broad, working familiarity with the spectrum of renewable energy technologies
Exposure and content.
Getting a sense of how each major type of renewable energy production works was very useful. I found the homeworks particularly helpful in this regard.
Learning the science beyond the technology of renewable energy. I found very interesting to be able to explain a technology even though one might be have a background in Engineering or science.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: There need to be additional resources for non-engineering students. PowerPoint slides need to define the variables every time an equation is given. Weekly problem sets ranged from being extremely easy to ridiculously difficult.

The pedagogy really needs a bit more work. Larry's lectures went into far too much detail about certain aspects -- people who knew that material were bored and people who didn't know the material were completely lost--he needs to edit it down to the crucial concepts (not start everything from first principles). Did we ever need to use the Coulombic Force? Simple enough to say charges attract each other (why give the formula/inverse square law)? Did we need to understand all those thermo engines? Better to concentrate on Carnot and really get it? Felt like we spent far too much time on that intro material and then rushed through interesting material. Would have loved to spend more time on geothermal, for example. Felt like a rushed grouping of definitions instead of a time to really master the thermo we spent so long on! Professors should hire a teaching assistant to go through the notes and add labels to variables/make them consistent. They really should be in better shape, given recommended text is relatively useless... Of course it's not instructors fault that there isn't a better book out there!
Problem set corrections/grading could be improved (see above).

Professor Larry Schwartz who co-taught the course was hard to follow during his lectures at times, and his slides were not very clear. He would not introduce an important equation or concept we were assumed to know as background, and he wasn't particularly helpful when you asked him a question about the background material or a problem set. In addition, it would be very useful to have access to answers to the problem sets after we received our grades so we could use them as a study tool. Otherwise it was very difficult to know what you did wrong on the problem sets if a few points were taken off but there was no explanation (and it wasn't clear which of the 3 TAs graded that particular problem set).
The topics covered by Schwartz need to be presented and explained more clearly
The homework assignments. The goal should be to understand, not to be challenged. I suggest drop in sessions, with QnA

I would urge Larry to clean up his Powerpoint slide presentations. Too often there were multiple equations pasted up with little explanation of what the variables stood for, or how/when the equation should be applied. I spent a lot of time googling equations for the hw assignments.
Organization, class time, textbook choice.

Many of the lectures given by Professor Schwartz were poorly organized and poorly explained. I understand that some of the material was complex, but the professor should have either reduced the amount of material taught or (better yet) simply gone over equations more carefully, with more explanation and greater clarity. One way of ensuring greater clarity might have been to use the white board rather than flashing inscrutable equations and diagrams on slides.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There were no discussion sections, but the office hours were very helpful in understanding how to do the problem sets.
yes
There were no structured discussion or lab sections, although there should have been.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This was a very valuable course for my Master of Environmental Management curriculum. The content was extremely relevant and was a good refresher for basic quantitative skills.
I'm a first year graduate student at F&ES.
My area of specialization is energy and the environment
This course fits perfectly in my overall program
I am interested in clean energy policy, and understanding the technologies pertaining to clean energy is an important aspect of my program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To gain a basic understanding to the engineering behind renewable energy technologies.
I wanted a grounding in the basic concepts of the course. I think I obtained that, so I am glad I took it. But I don't think the current org of course is well thought out...
I am interested in this topic
To develop a basic understanding of renewable energy systems.
I would like to work in the renewables industry
I wanted to dust off my knowledge of renewable energy and really understand the science behind those technologies
I have become more interested in energy issues -- particularly in relation to water -- and this course provided a broad introduction to renewable technologies.
To fulfill my energy specialization at the school of Forestry and environmental studies. And also for my own understanding.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Overall yes--but was at times frustrating for wrong reasons (pedagogy) instead of concepts.
Yes
Yes, in general.
Yes, this is really excellent content
Yes, although it was a struggle at times for someone who had never taken a physics course.
Yes, mostly. Would have liked a better more useful textbook.
Yes, the knowledge did meet my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working in group with classmates to approach assignments was helpful

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Get a really good intro physics textbook. I found R. Shankar's Fundamentals of Physics super helpful (along with his lectures on Yale Open Courses).
Make sure you have a basic understanding of physics
I highly recommend this course. If you want to get a clear understanding of renewable energy, take this class. Be however prepared to spend some hours every week on this course.
Make sure you are comfortable with basic physics concepts!
Study physics, get a better textbook.
